original_data.question: A 40-year-old obese man with a history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease presents with one day of excruciating pain, swelling, and redness in his greater toe. He denies any inciting trauma or similar prior episodes. Vital signs are stable. On examination, the right first toe is grossly erythematous and edematous, with range of motion limited due to pain. Deposition of which of the following is associated with the most likely underlying joint disorder?

model_response:
This is a case of acute gouty arthritis. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of urate crystals in the synovial fluid of affected joints. Hyperuricemia is present in approximately half of patients with gout. The most common joint involved in gout is the first metatarsophalangeal joint (the great toe). Calcium phosphate crystals are deposited in the joints in cases of calcific periarthritis. Calcium oxalate crystals are deposited in the kidney in cases of ethylene glycol poisoning. Monosodium urate crystals are deposited in the joints in cases of gout. Copper deposits are seen in Wilson disease.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the recommended standards, usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX, a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).
Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Record and study of past events.
Impairment of the renal function secondary to chronic kidney damage persisting for three or more months.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.
Any one of five terminal digits of the vertebrate FOOT.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
The quality of being free from change or variation or not taking part readily in chemical change.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The innermost digit of the foot in PRIMATES.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Accumulation of extraneous inorganic matter in tissues or cavities.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
